required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study on the Pain Control Effect of the Anesthetic Method During Prostate Biopsy: Comparison Between Pelvic Plexus Block and Periprosthetic Nerve Block
clinical_study.official_title: What is the Most Effective Local Anesthesia for Prostate-stained Ultrasonography-guided Biopsy in PPB and PNB?: A Single Center, Prospective, Randomized, Double Arm Study

brief_summary.textblock: This study assesses differences in the effects of pelvic plexus block and periprostatic nerve block among various anesthetic methods that reduce the pain caused by prostate biopsy.

detailed_description.textblock: Recently, various types of local anesthetic methods have been attempted to reduce biopsy-related pain leading to changes in the type of anesthetic agents and site of injection. Of these anesthetics and combinations, pelvic plexus block and periprostatic nerve block seem to be the very effective way to control prostate biopsy-related pain. However, few studies have compared these two methods.

primary_outcome.description: Visual analog scale (0-10) during anesthesia procedure higher values represent a worse outcome.
Visual analog scale (0-10) at insertion of ultrasound probe higher values represent a worse outcome.
Visual analog scale (0-10) during biopsy procedure higher values represent a worse outcome.
Visual analog scale (0-10) at 15 min after the biopsy procedure higher values represent a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.description: Total time taken for prostate biopsy

clinical_study.condition: Transrectal Systematic Prostate Biopsy Related Pain

arm_group.description: The injections of 2.5 mL of 2% lidocaine were made to the pelvic neurovascular plexus located at the end of the seminal vesicle under Doppler US guidance on each side
The injections of 2.5 mL of 2% lidocaine were made to the neurovascular bundles at the junction of the prostate-bladder-seminal vesicle.

intervention.description: Injections of 2.5 mL of 2% lidocaine were made to the pelvic neurovascular plexus located at the end of the seminal vesicle under Doppler US guidance on each side
Injections of 2.5 mL of 2% lidocaine were made to the neurovascular bundles at the junction of the prostate-bladder-seminal vesicle on each side.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- abnormal prostate finding on digital rectal examination
- serum PSA level of > 2.5 ng/mL
- Transrectal ultrasonographic abnormal lesion
Exclusion Criteria:
- under 50 years old
- a history of previous TRUS-guided biopsy
- chronic prostatitis/pelvic pain
- neurological conditions (dementia, Parkinson disease, or cerebral infarction)
- bleeding diathesis
- active UTI
- hemorrhoids/anal fissure/anal fistula
- known allergy to lidocaine

facility.name: Yonsei University Medical College Gangnam Severance Hospital
